2473

Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (VII of 1947)

Citation: 5(2) LNJ 30,

Case Year: 1947

Subject: Foreign Exchange

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (VII of 1947)

Section 18

If the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act is read as a whole, there is no doubt in assuming that a foreigner who owns any immoveable property in Bangladesh cannot sell his/her property to another foreigner without prior permission of the Bangladesh Bank because of the fact that such transaction which involves sale of any property of a resident in Bangladesh involves taking the sale proceeds of the property in foreign currency.  Chairman, RAJUK and others Vs. Manzur Ahmed and others, (Civil), 5(2) LNJ 30

Section 20

A plain reading of these provisions clearly show that any person who has been a resident in Bangladesh, that is to say, Mrs. Inge Flatz, cannot make any payment or receive foreign currency whether it is consideration or otherwise to any person outside Bangladesh in respect of any property in Bangladesh. Chairman, RAJUK and others Vs. Manzur Ahmed and others, (Civil), 5(2) LNJ 30

Sections 20 and 21

The object for promulgating this law is to restrict, regulate payments, dealings with foreign exchange and other related matters. If any such transaction which involves foreign currency by a resident in Bangladesh is made without prior permission of the Bangladesh Bank, the economic and financial interest of the country will be affected.  Chairman, RAJUK and others Vs. Manzur Ahmed and others, (Civil), 5(2) LNJ 30

Section 21(1)

The words "in any way the operation of any provision" have been used and the language is wide enough to infer that no resident in Bangladesh can deal with any transaction in respect of any property in Bangladesh which involves payment of foreign currency with any other person resident in Bangladesh without prior permission of Bangladesh Bank because of the simple reason that if such transaction is allowed anybody can siphon the foreign currency to any foreign country by selling his immovable property in Bangladesh and in that case, the government will be deprived of the foreign currency. Chairman, RAJUK and others Vs. Manzur Ahmed and others, (Civil), 5(2) LNJ 30

2474

Foreigners Act (XXX of 1946)

Citation: (1968) 20 DLR 423.

Case Year: 1946

Subject: Foreigners Act

Delivery Date: 2018-04-05

                                                                         Foreigners Act (XXX of 1946)

S. 14: Quit notice to a foreigner— Contravention of every successive notice to quit constitutes fresh offence and there­fore, fresh prosecution after conviction under the same section (S. 14)— Permissible.

Three foreigners were convicted under section 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946. On appeal the lower appellate court held that previous prosecutions under section 14 of the Foreigners Act were a bar to fresh prosecutions under the same section. The High Court reversed the findings of the lower appellate Court on the ground that every contravention of eve­ry notice to quit constituted a fresh offence under section 14 and as such fresh prosecution was permis­sible. Govt, of East Pakistan Vs. Jilani Khan, (1968) 20 DLR 423.

2475

Foreigners Order of 1951

Citation: (1955) 7 DLR 352, (1959) 11 DLR (WP) 83; (1959) PLD (Kar) 94, (1954) 6 DLR (FC) 206(218l-h.col), (1986) 38 DLR 86, (1954) 6 DLR(FC)206 (218 l-h.col), (1978) 30 DLR 49, (1978) 30 DLR 49, (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102, (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102, (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102

Case Year: 1951

Subject: Foreigners Order

Delivery Date: 2018-04-09

Foreigners Order of 1951

 

Clause 11. Use of the provisions of the Foreigners Order in the case is a fraud on statute.

The restrictions sought to be imposed upon the movement of the petitioner under the Foreigners Or­der constitutes a clear fraud on the Foreigners Order in the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case, because of the legal battle that is being waged by this petitioner against the executive authority for se­curing General Clauses Act (X of 1897)

S. 5(1)—Acts of Parliament to become opera­tive do not depend upon their publication in Gazette.

If the Federal Legislature which is a sovereign body states that an Act or a Resolution passed by it shall become law at once nobody can say that it will not. If it does not fix any day for the commencement of the Act, the commencement is governed by sec­tion 5(i) of the General Clauses Act, that is to say, it comes into force as soon as the assent of the Gov­ernor-General is given. Supdt. and L.Remcmb. oj L.Affairs, Govt, of E.Bengal Vs. Syed Ashraf Mi (1955) 7 DLR 352.

 

S. 6—Effect of repeal of enactment.

According to section 6(c) of the Act (Central) when an Act repeals any enactment, then, unless a different intention appears, the repeal docs not affect  any investigation or legal proceedings already insti­tuted. Muhammad Irtiza Vs. Stale (1959) 11 DLR (WP) 83; (1959) PLD (Kar) 94.

—In respect of statutes which take away rights under existing laws, there is a presumption that they are not intended to have retrospective effect. LtMahhub Khan Vs. Crown (1954) 6 DLR (FC) 206(218l-h.col).

—Only cases pending trials before a tribunal which had taken cognizance of the offence shall be tried by such tribunal when the amending law came into force changing the forum of trial. Sakya Pada Barua Vs. State (1986) 38 DLR 86.

Ss. 6. 6(c)(e) & 6(e)

Law taking away right—No retro-spective effect.

Section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, [deals with the effect of repeal by a Central Act, Clause(c) of section 6 makes it clear that even if these proceedings be regarded as still pending, they cannot be affected by the subsequent repeal and they must be continued as if the repealing statue had not been passed. Lt.Mahhub Khan Vs. Crown (1954) 6 DLR(FC)206 (218 l-h.col).

 

The High Court Division was the forum 1 appeals were to be filed u/s. 30 of the Special Jcrs Act before its amendment on 29th July, 1974. By this amendment this right to appeal to Court abolished—Judgment of conviction upon the accused under Special Powers Act was pronounced  and appeal was filed in the High Court after amendment came into effect. —Held : In spite of [amendment High Court Division still remains Ibrum of appeal which is accused's vested right la continuation of pending proceeding. mzimuddln Vs. State (1978) 30 DLR 49.

 

—Repeal of a law followed by fresh lation—Mode of interpretation.

In case of repeal of a law followed by fresh legislion on the same subject, the line of inquiry lid be not to find out whether the new law cx-lly keeps alive rights and liabilities accrued or  under the repealed law, but whether mani-la clear intention to destroy them. Md. Nazi-pMin Vs. Slate (1978) 30 DLR 49.

 

Applicability of S.6

Section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 is cable to a simple case of repeal, as well as to a  repeal of a statute followed by fresh enact­ment the same subject. Section 6 would be applicable unless the new legislation manifests an intention –incompatible with or contrary to the provisions of the section, and such incompatibility would have ascertained from consideration of all the rele­vant provision of the new law. Md. Nazimuddin Vs. Slate (1978) 30 DLR 49.

 

S. 6(c)(e)—Effect of repeal of a stat­ute read with a saving clause.

 

  The general principle that an enactment which is repealed is to be treated as if it had never existed is subject to any saving which may be made expressly or by implication by the repealing enactment. Akh-tar I/ossain Vs. State (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102.

 

—Police investigations into offences falling un­der P.O. 50 of 1972 pending, when P.O. 50 was re­pealed—That will not invalidate the pending investi­gations as provided by sec. 6(2c)(e) of the General Clauses Act. Akhtar Hossain Vs. State (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102

 

—Repealing Act i.e. P.O. XIV of 1974 does not show that offences which were cognizable under P.O. 50 but did not come before the Court through submissions of charge-sheet were intended to be de­stroyed by the legislature.

 

  There is nothing to show from the provisions of the repealing Act that any intention contrary to the saving provisions of s.6(c) and (c) of the General Clauses Act has been expressed in the Act with a view to show that the legislature intended to destroy the offences committed under P.O. 50 up to the date of its repeal but did not come before the court through submission of charge-sheet under Article 4 (1) of P.O. 50. Provisions of section 6 of the Gener­al Clauses Act must come into operation in case of repeal of an cnacuncnt and in that view of the matter the proceedings in respect of offences of P.O. 50 pending investigation with the police must be cov­ered by the provisions of s.6(c) and (c) of the Gener­al Clauses Act. Akhtar Hossain Vs. State (1977) 29 DLR (SC)102.

 

  S. 6(e)—Investigation or proceedings started under P.O. 50/72 will be continued under the provi­sions of the Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) by viratue of section 6(c) of the General Clauses Act in spite of the repeal of P.O. 50/72. Hasan Ali Dafiary Vs. The State (1975) 27 DLR 561.

—Ss. 6(e), 21 & 26 

—Procedural law—General principle is that procedural law is retrospective—Law altered during pendency of suit.

 

  When the law is altered during the pendency of an action, the rights of the parties arc to be decided according to the law as it existed when the action was begun, unless the new statute shows a clear in­tention to vary such rights. Where the legislature has made its intention clear that the amending Act should have retrospective operation, there is no doubt that it must be so construed even though the consequences may entail hardship to a party.

 

  But even without express words to that effect, retrospective effect may be given to an amending law, if the new law manifests such a necessary in­tendment.

 

  With regard to the procedural laws, the general principle is that alterations in procedure arc retro­spective unless there be some good reason against such a view. Mohammad Alam Vs. The State, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 242.

 

 —Applicability of the section.

  Section 6(c) of the General Clauses Act would have application when there is a repeal of any enact­ment. In the present case there has been an amend­ment to affect the jurisdiction of the Court and such amendment cannot be put at par with the repeal of a statute with or without a saving clause. Bangladesh Vs. Shahjahan Siraj (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 1.

 

  S. 21—Order of the Government un­der section 401, Cr.P.C, when can be re­called.

 

  An order passed by the Provincial Government under section 401 of the Cr.P.C. is subject to modi­fication or recall by virtue of section 21 of the Gen­eral Clauses Act provided that the previous order has not yet been acted upon. Shahbaz Vs. Crown (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 91.

 

—If, however, previous order has been given effeet to, so that no locus poenitcnliae is left, there will be no occasion for the exercises of the power  mentioned in section 21 of the General Clauses Act ShahbazVs. Crown (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 91.

 

—Sub-section (3) of section 401 of the Cr.P.Code does not necessarily imply that the gcnJ al provisions of section 21 of the General Clause! Act arc protanto negatived. Such an inference should not be drawn unless it is inevitable and the language of the two statutes is absolutely irreconcilable able. Shahbaz Vs. Crown (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 91.

 

  S. 26—Double punishment for same offence—Barred.

 

  The only statutory provision which recognizes the rule against double jeopardy arc provided in sci lion 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and section 26 of the General Clauses Act, 1897. The former a second trial; the latter prohibits a person from being punished twice for the same offeneef M.S.K.lbrat Vs. Commander-in-Chief (1956} DLR (SC) 128 (132 rt-h.col).

 

 —Conviction under two penal laws is valid b sentence can be awarded only under cither of the ivl Md. Farooq Vs. Slate (1956) 8 DLR (SC) 135.

 

—Accused cannot be sentenced under s.161 P.P.C., and also under sec. 5(2) of the Preventing Corruption Acl, though his conviction under d two sections is valid in view of section 235, clauses  (2) of the Criminal Procedure Code. Md. Yusufm Crown (1955) 7 DLR 302.

 

—Militates against rule of implied repeal.

 

—An offender can be prosecuted under J more than one enactment. Md. Hayui Vs Crown (1954) 6 DLR (WP) 68 (74).

 

—Section 26 operates to obviate altogether implied repeal of one penal law by another. The lion docs not deal only with the matter of punish­ment; it provides also that the person offending may be prosecuted under any or all the relevant en­actments. ALatif Vs. Crown (1953) 5 DLR (WP) 40.

 

—The rule contained in section 26 applies even where the subsequent enactment which may be brought into play for punishing the offender pro­vides a special procedure governing the trial for such an offence. A.Lalif Vs. Crown (1953) 5 DLR (WP) 40.

 

—Section 403 of the Criminal Procedure Code as well as section 26 of the General Clauses Act would go to show that when a person is not being tried again for the same offence, he cannot be heard to say that because he had been acquitted previously and that acquittal is still in force, he is not liable to be tried again for the same offence, or on the same facts for any other offence for which a charge against him might have been made under section 236, Crim­inal Procedure Code or for which he might have been convicted under section 237 of the Code. Ghu-lamNabi Vs. State (1966) 18 DLR (WP) 82.

 

—Conviction under two laws.

 

   Conviction under two separate statutes (in the present case under section 409 of Pakistan Penal Code and section 5(2) of Act II of 1947) lawful but imposing separate and independent punishment for each conviction, that is, double punishment, is pro­hibited.

 

  The accused has been found guilty under section 409, P.P.C. read with section 5(2) of Act (II of 1947) and has been sentenced under section 409 P.P.C. The position is that the accused has been found guilty under both the provisions of law, i.e., under section 409 P.P.C. as well as under section 5 (2) of the Act (II of 1947). The learned Special Judge did not pass any separate sentence under section 5(2) of the Act (II of 1947) but passed the sentence only under section 409, P.P.C.

 

  Held : Section 26 of the General Clauses Act prohibits punishment under two different enact­ments; but it docs not prohibit trial or conviction under those enactments.

 

   Furthermore, section 5(4) of Act (II of 1947) says that the provisions of section 5 are in addition to and not in derogation of any other law for the time being in force and nothing contained in that section shall exempt any public servant from any proceedings which could be instituted against him. There is similar provision in section 71 of the Paki­stan Penal Code which prohibits punishing an of­fender for more than once for the same act which is punishable under one or more definitions. Thus the law and principle contained in section 26 of the Gen­eral Clauses Act, section 5(4) of Act (II of 1947) and section 71 of the Pakistan Penal Code, is the same, i.e., double punishment is prohibited but trial and conviction for different offences arc not all prohibit­ed. Muhammad Sadiq Javeed Vs. The Slate, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 63.

Guardians and Wards Act (VIII of 1890)

S. 25—Proceeding under section 488, Cr.P.Code maintainable even where a suit for custo­dy of the minor is pending before a civil court under section 25 of the Guardians and Wards Act.

 

There is nothing illegal if during the pendency of the guardianship case the Trial Magistrate pro­ceeded with the case and ordered the payment of maintenance allowance. Khan Md. Vs. Mst. Gohar Banu (1965) 17 DLR (WP) 42.

 

—Father applied for custody of female child on her attaining puberty, the guardian Judge rejected the application—Order for payment of maintenance of such child passed by the Magistrate previous to such rejection continues binding upon the father. Abdus Salam Vs. Mst. Razia Begum (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 288.

2478

Imports and Exports (Control) Act (XXXIX of 1950)

Citation: (1958) 10 DLR(WP) 46, 1963) 15 DLR (WP) 3, (1968) 20 DLR 546, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 321.

Case Year: 1950

Subject: Imports and Exports (Control)

Delivery Date: 2018-04-25

                                  Imports and Exports (Control) Act  (XXXIX of 1950)

            

Ss. 3(3) and 2(c)—It was contended as much as the goods in respect of which a r lion under sub-section (I) of section 3 of this Act has been made shall be deemed to be the goods of which the export and import have been prohibited or restricted under section 19 of the Sea Customs Act, the prohibition or restriction cannot be extended to goods which have been brought by air since section 19 of the Sea Customs Act does not in terms refer to goods brought by air.

 

Held : In view of the definition of the word Import' as given in section 2 of the Imports and Ex­ports (Control) Act, section 19 of the Sea Customs Act and all its provisions would apply to goods brought by air also. Lt.Col.Syed Naiycr Reza Vs. Pak. (1958) 10 DLR(WP) 46.

 

—Provisions of the Act apply only to goods imported into or exported out of Pakistan—It does not apply to means of transport used for removal of such goods—Grant of option under section 3(3) dis­cretionary only in respect of contraband goods and not in respect of vehicles used as means of convey­ance for removal of such goods. Murad Ali Vs. Collector, Central Excise (1963) 15 DLR (WP) 3.

 

S. 6 : Cognizance of offence under section 167 (8)(81) on the report of E.P.R. personnel is without jurisdiction.

 

Section 6 of the Imports and Exports Act which lays down that no Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under section 5 of the said Act except upon complaint in writing by a Customs Controller or the Chief Controller or any officer authorized in that behalf and that no Court inferior to that of Magistrate of the first class shall try any such offence.

 

The offence in the present cases were punishable under section 167(8)(81) of the Sea Customs Act. That being so, the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the cases on the complaint by the E.P.R. personnel except complaint made in writing by the Customs authorities. Tamjid Ali Vs. The State (1968) 20 DLR 546.

 

—Offence falling both under the Sea Customs

 

Act and Imports and Exports Control Act— Prosecution of accused only under the Sea Customs Act competent.

 

 

Accused for committing the offence of smug­gling bidi leaves was liable to be charged both under section 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act as well as under section 3 of the Imports and Exports (Control) Act. Prosecution under section 6 of the Imports and Exports Control Act for violation of the provisions under section 3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act could be upon complaint in writing of the rele­vant authorities. In the present case the accused was, however, charged under section 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act which was a cognizable offence and for the prosecution of which no complaint by any Cus­tom Officer is necessary. It was contended that the accused being liable for prosecution both under the Sea Customs as well as under the Import & Exports Control Acts, his prosecution and trial under section 167 (81) of the Sea Customs Act alone was illegal and the Magistrate taking cognizance of the case un­der section 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act (which requires no written complaint by Custom Officer) without his prosecution under the Imports and Ex­ports Control Act, which requires written complaint, was illegal and, therefore, the trial held was illegal and without jurisdiction.

 

 

Held : The prosecution having not chosen to prosecute the accused under the Imports and Exports Control Act there was nothing illegal and no want of jurisdiction if the accused is prosecuted and tried under the Sea Customs Act. Saleh Mohammad Vs.' The State. (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 321.

Judicial Officers' Protection Act (XVIII of 1850)

Citation: (I960) 12 DLR (WP) 78; (1960) PLD(Lah) 1039,(196012 DLR (WP) 78: (1960) PLD (Lah) 1039, (1960) 12 DLR (WP) 78: (1960) PLD 1039, 54 CWN (2 DR) 71.

Case Year: 1850

Subject: Judicial Officers' Protection

Delivery Date: 2018-04-25

                             Judicial Officers' Protection Act (XVIII of 1850)

 

S. 1—Cause of action against an offi­cer who makes an order of arrest-Jurisdiction to pass the order—Burden of proof of good faith.

 

If the judicial officer had jurisdiction to make an order of arrest or detention which is made the basis of a suit by the person arrested or detained, there is no cause of action for the suit. If, on the other hand, such jurisdiction did not exist the question as to

Whether  the plaintiff is entitled to damages will be tided in accordance with the proviso to the section i.e if the judicial officer believed in good faith that d jurisdiction to do or order the act complained of he will not be liable in damages.

(Belief in good faith referred to in the section be a belief based on reasonable grounds. Khan Qadir Khan Vs. A.K.Khalid (I960) 12 DLR (WP) 78; (1960) PLD(Lah) 1039.

Magistrate on account of annoyance issuing t instance non-bailable warrant of arrest for of-undcr section 182, P.P.C. without there being plaint before him—Proviso held inapplicable. Gulam Qadir Khan Vs. A.K.Khalid (196012 DLR (WP) 78: (1960) PLD (Lah) 1039.

-Damages—For false imprisonment—No hard fast rule—Such a suit brought more for vindica-Jof honour than money—Rs. 500 awarded in for Rs. 20,000. Khan Gulam Qadir Khan Vs. halid (1960) 12 DLR (WP) 78: (1960) PLD 1039.

 

Jurisdiction in the Judicial Officers' Protcc-ct means authority and power to act in a mat-t authority and power to do an act in a particu-m or manner. A Magistrate who is used for jgful arrest or detention is protected under the Hal Officer's Protection Act as soon as he shows he was acting in the discharge of his judicial and within jurisdiction. 54 CWN (2 DR) 71.

2482

Law Reforms Ordinance (XLIX of 1978)

Citation: (1983) 35 DLR 1, (1983) 35 DLR 369

Case Year: 1978

Subject: Law Reforms

Delivery Date: 2018-04-25

                                 Law Reforms Ordinance (XLIX of 1978)

 

Accused was discharged by the Magistrate before Ordinance 49 of 1978 came into force on 1.6.79. Hence his case will be governed by the provisions of C.P.Code according to section 6 of the General Clauses Act.

 

The order of commitment to the Court of Ses­sions in the instant case was passed before the Law Reforms Ordinance, 1978 (Ord. XLIX of 1978) came into force on 1.6.79. The said Law Reforms Ordi­nance repealed, inter alia, section 437 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, by providing in its schedule that section 437 shall be omitted. But since the ac­cused petitioner was discharged by the enquiring Magistrate before the Law Reforms Ordinance, 1978 came into force his case, according to section 6 of the General Clauses Act 1897, will be governed by the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure as they existed before the coming into force of the said Law Reforms Ordinance 1978, as if the repealing Act had not been passed. Fazlul 11 uq Vs. State, (1983)35 DLR 1.

 

S. 4(1)—Pending proceeding before the Magis­trate not affected by the Law Reforms Ordinance.

 

The present case was pending for inquiry before the Magistrate when the Law Reforms Ordinance came into force.

 

Question is whether in view of promulgation of Law Reforms Ordinance, 1978 the enquiry under chapter XVIII of the Code of Criminal Procedure which was pending in the instant case could be held or the records be transmitted to the Court of Ses­sions without any such inquiry.

 

Held : The instant proceeding which was pend­ing for inquiry shall be deemed to be pending pro­ceeding within the meaning of section 4(1) of the Law Reforms Ordinance.

 

The learned Magistrate is accordingly directed to complete the proceedings under Chapter XVIII of die repelled Code of Criminal Procedure from the stage. where it was left. Md. Moklesur Rahman Vs. k.F.M.Moshin (1983) 35 DLR 369

2483

M.L. Act I of 1979

Citation: (1981)33 DLR 358, (1981) 33 DLR 348, (1981) 33 DLR 348, 1981) 33 DLR 348

Case Year: 1979

Subject: M.L.

Delivery Date: 2018-05-06

                                                                     M.L. Act   I of 1979

 

Both the last Proclamation of Martial Law and Act 1 of 1979 saving Martial Law were issued on the same day, i.e., on 6th April, 1979. The specific period ascribed in the last Martial Law Proclamation for saving all Martial Law Proclamations, Regula­tions, Orders, acts and actions however extended be­yond the period from date and lime of the withdrawal of Marlial Law on 6th April upto 9th April, 1979.

The review authorities under clauses (c) and (f) of the last proclamation of Marlial Law were obliged to complclc the pending continuing proceedings of Martial Law Courts by making a final review order thereon within 9lh April, 1979 at the latest, since Ihcrcaftcr no act or action of any continuing surviv­ing authorities of Martial Law administration like the review authorities have been saved and ratified by the Parliament under Act I of 1979.

Any order made by the reviewing authorities un­der clauses (e) and (f) of the last proclamation of Martial Law beyond 9th April, 1979 was not man­dated by the Parliament under Act I of 1979 and con­sequently such act and action would under any cir­cumstances be acts and actions without any lawful authority with no legal effect having constitutional sanction.

In such circumstances, the review of the pro­ceeding taken before the Special Martial Law Court by the Government having been made on 17th April, 1979 and the review of the proceeding taken before the Summary Martial Law Court made by the Session Judge on 10th and 18th April 1979 were all having been done and made after 9lh April, 1979 and were taken and done without any lawful authority with no legal effect. Consequently the review of the proceedings of the Martial Law Courts being a con­tinuation of the proceeding to reach the finality thereof having been held to have been done without any lawful authority, the conviction and sentence imposed by the Martial Law Courts in the respective judgments and orders lose all validity for further en­forcement and becomes a nullity in law.

In the result the review made by the Govern­ment and the Session Judge with regard to the pro­ceedings taken against the petitioners before the Martial Law Courts is hereby declared to have been done without any lawful authority and consequently the conviction and sentence imposed by the Martial Law Courts against the petitioners in the respective proceeding having not been reviewed within the specified period in accordance with law, arc declared to have no legal effect and in the result the petition­ers are set at liberty. Rczaul Karim Vs. Govt, of Bangladesh (1981)33 DLR 358.

—In view of the fact that the acts and actions of the reviewing authority reviewing cases after the fi­nal withdrawal of the Martial Law (June 6.4.79) continue to be the acts and actions under Martial Law, what is the effect of such acts and actions of the reviewing authority after the final withdrawal of Martial Law read with Act I of 1979.

Held: Under the provisions of the last procla­mation of Martial Law while lifting the Martial Law, the respective authorities have been empowered to review the proceedings already terminable before Martial Law Courts even after the final withdrawal of Martial Law.

In such circumstances the only and final ques­tion is whether such continuing acts and actions of the reviewing authorities being deemed to be acts and actions of marlial law authorities were saved and ratified by the Parliament in Act 1 of 1979 being the 5lh 

other review authority. A review judgment passed by M.L. Court offers no right of hearing or the person's personal appearance; as such, it is not a substantive right which could not be altered by amendment whereby a former review authority is changed by ap­pointment of another review authority—In the ab­sence of any right of personal appearance, etc., the person concerned is not prejudiced by mere alteration of review forum. Kh Moshtaque Ahmed Vs. Govt, of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 348.

—The jurisdiction of the Government to review the judgments of Special Military Courts was given by the amendment of the Regulation No. 4 of Mar­tial Law Regulation 1 of 1975 by which the Chief Martial Law Administrator has been substituted by the Government. To consider whether that review of the petitioner's case by the Chief Martial Law Ad­ministrator is a vested right or not we have to con­sider what are the nature of these rights. Right to re­examine witnesses, right of appeal arc substantive rights and cannot be taken away by amendment of the procedure available to a parly. A review of judg­ment of Martial Law Court by any authority docs not provide any right of hearing or personal appear­ance by the party aggrieved and no action has to be taken by the party concerned. As such it cannot be said to be a substantive right which could not be al­tered of the judgment passed by the Martial Law Court.

Further, it is to be seen as to how the party's right has been affected or he has been prejudiced by the change of the authority competent to review the judgment of the Special Martial Law Court. In the absence of any right of personal appearance or any­thing to be done by the party, he has not in any way been prejudiced by the change of the forum of review from C.M.L.A. to the Government. The review has not been taken away but kept intact. It is only the [reviewing authority that has been changed and as such it has not prejudiced the petitioner. Kh Mos-taque  Ahmed Vs. Govt, of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR348.

 

—In the matter of review of judgment referred to in Reg. 4, the Govt, has to exercise its mind judi­2. Mohammadan Law cially and that should be apparent on the face of the record which is lacking here.

It has been held by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court that the Government may dis­pose of the review in the manner they deemed proper in the absence of any particular mode laid down for reviewing the matter. Whatever may be our views with regard to the question of review the decision of the Appellate Division stands in our way in coming to any finding with regard to the question whether the review that is referred to in Regulation No. 4 is a judicial review or not. We, however, think that in reviewing the judgments of the M.L. Courts the Government should exercise its judicial mind that should be apparent on the review order passed by the government and that is absent in the present cases. But in view of the Appellate Division's judgment we cannot hold that the review in the instant case was not in accordance with law.

Said laws are immune from challenge in view of the Proclamation of 20th August, 1975 contain­ing clauses (d), (e) and (g) therein.

It that view of the matter we do not find any substance in the arguments advanced by the learned Advocate for the petitioner. The points argued by the learned Advocate for the petitioner are covered by the decisions of the Appellate Division and in that view of the matter, these two petitions must fail. Kh Moshtaque Ahmed Vs. Govt, of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 348.

Muhummadan Law

Citation: (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 45, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 104.

Subject: Muhummadan Law

Delivery Date: 2018-05-06

                                           Muhummadan Law

 

Father being the legal guardian of the minors, taking the minors from the mother's custody by the father docs not amount to kidnapping.The legal guardian has in law constructive cus­tody of the minor children. He can also claim that he bonafide believed himself entitled to their custody and thus not guilty of kidnapping his own children when he removes them from the hizanat of the mi­nor. Ahmed Nawaz and ors. Vs. The State, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 45.

—Custody of married minor girl.

Mother and not husband entitled to custody of minor wife until she attains puberty—Married minor girl's detention by husband without mother's consent illegal.

According to the Muslim Law, the effect of the contract of marriage is to place the wife under the domain of the husband, but that notwithstanding her marriage, the right to the care and custody of a mi­nor girl belongs not to the husband, but to her mother until she attains the age of puberty. The law­ful guardianship and custody of a minor Muslim girl is with the mother even as against the husband. Where the female is a minor and is kept out from the custody of natural guardian against her wishes, such detention is illegal, as it is without the consent of the person who is legally entitled to the custody of the minor. Muhammad Lalif Vs. Akbar Ali, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 104.

Municipal Administration Ordinance (X of 1960)

Citation: (1970) 22 DLR 300, (1974) 26 DLR 350, (1966) 18 DLR 212, (1967)19 DLR 684, (1967) 19 DLR 684, (1967) 19 DLR 684, (1974) 26 DLR 350

Case Year: 1960

Subject: Municipal Administration Ordinance

Delivery Date: 2018-05-06

                                Municipal Administration Ordinance (X of 1960)

 

S. 45(3)(c)—Landlord cannot be held respon­sible for the tenant's act in respect of an unauthor­ised construction of a latrine.

In the present case the tenants thcmsclcvs con­structed an unauthorised kutcha latrine in the tenant­ed holding which was liable to be removed as con­struction of such latrine was an offence under section 45(3) (c) of the Ordinance.

Question arose whether it was the tenant's or the landlord's liability to remove the latrine or other­wise to undergo punishment.

Held: Notice for removal of the latrine shall be served on the owner of the construction that is the tenant and not on the owner of the premises. Munic­ipality Dinajpur Vs. Abdul Wahid Majumder, (1970) 22 DLR 300.

Ss. 77& 83—Sentence—In default of pay­ment of fine proper course is to impose simple im­prisonment.

Accused charged under sections 77 and 83 of the J Municipal Administration Ordinance 1960 wasconj victed and sentenced to a fine of Rs.50/- only, in del fault to suffer R.I. for one month. Held: The ordal sentencing the accused to undergo R.I. in defaulto payment of fine is bad in law. In such a case till proper course is to impose simple imprisonment! Nizamuddin Mia Vs. The State, (1974) 26 DLR 350.

 

Sees. 83 and 116—Simultaneous procced| ings under section 83 and 116 permissible.The Municipality can proceed simultaneous!! under sections 83 and 116 of the Ordinance whiclj are meant for two different purposes, the first one fofl removal of the encroachment and the second one fori encroachment punishable under the law. Amir Hos] sain Vs. Z. Hasan, (1966) 18 DLR 212.

 

—Sees. 115 and 116—"Continuing ofl fence"—Accused convicted in the first trial undcl sections 115 and 116 of the Municipal Administral tion Ordinance—He was convicted in a 2nd trial un| dcr the same sections and sentenced to pay 20/-dicm till he stopped running the mill—Punishment! thus envisaged permissible. Amanullah Molla Ks| Dhaka Municipality, (1967)19 DLR 684.

—Question arose whether the second conviction! is not barred under section 403, Criminal Procedure! Code since this was a conviction for the second timel for the same offence.

In the present case, we are concerned with thel Municipal Administration Ordinance which itself! provides for punishment for more than once. It is a I special law and provisions of this Ordinance will es- [ sentially guide and govern the present case. But here I no special mode of trial has been provided and so, the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure! would apply. It is expressly provided that if the of-[ fence is continuing the offender could be punished tot pay a fine of Rs. 20/- every day. On the principle! laid down in 13 DLR 892 by the Special Bench that.

 

if punishment is sought for the second time for con­tinuing offence, by continuation the offence is repet­itive. It is merely the continuation of the offence. It follows that these acts can be punished as laid down in the present Ordinance. Amanullah Molla Vs. Dhaka Municipality, (1967) 19 DLR 684.

S. 116—Magistrate convicted and sentenced the accused to pay a fine of Rs. 20/- each day so long as he goes on running his saw mill—The sen­tence is illegal.

There is no doubt that the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to the case in the matter of proce­dure as no particular procedure has been laid down by the Ordinance in question. Under the section 234 of the Code, not more than three offences can be tried at one trial if they are committed within one year. But here in the present case, there is no knowing for how many fresh offences the trial took place and the petitioner has been convicted and punished. All it says is from the date of his last conviction up to the end of his continuation of the running of the Mill. On the face it, it is vague, indefinite and without any limit of time. It cannot be the intention of the said Ordinance to punish a man without any limit of time and with complete disregard to the rules of pro­cedure prescribed for criminal trials. For any offence under the criminal law, there must be some definite mode of trial, definite accusations and all necessary particulars of the offences.

Since no definite accusations has been made as to the offences and other essential particulars so it is illegal under the provisions of section 234 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

There must be some limit to any punishment for any kind of offences and that limit of punish­ment at least must be upto the limit of the maxi­mum powers of a Court. Therefore, the punishment awarded in the present case is obviously illegal be­cause the Magistrate has no jurisdiction to impose such amount of fines as he has done in the present case. Amanullah Molla Vs. Dhaka Municipality, (1967) 19 DLR 684.

Sees. 116 and 83, Section 83—of the Ordinance deals with en­croachment over a street or drain and not with en­croachment of any municipal land. Therefore, the ac­cused's conviction under section 116 read with section 83 of the Municipal Administration Ordi­nance for encroachment of any municipal land is bad in law. Nizamuddin Mia Vs. The State (1974) 26 DLR 350.

S. 7—A Nikah Registrar is a public servant— The mere fact that the Nikah registrar is remunerated by fees to be received from the parlies docs not pre­vent his becoming a public servant if he is other­wise discharging a public duty Compulsory registration of marriages provided for by the Ordinance is clearly a public duty under­taken by the Government. Official Secrets Act (XIX of 1923)

Citation: (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 128.

Case Year: 1923

Subject: Official Secrets Act (XIX of 1923)

Delivery Date: 2018-05-06

   Official Secrets Act (XIX of 1923)

 

S.14—Magistrate ordering the hearing of a case in camera can only do so after being satisfied that it is necessary for the safety of the State.

It is obligatory that the discretion vested in the Magistrate under section 14 of the Official Secrets Act is exercised by him properly and judicially. A mere desire on the part of the Public Prosecutor who made the application to hold the proceeding of the Court in camera will not be enough to exclude pub­lic hearing and to justify an order for hearing in cam­era. It must be shown that the paramount object was safety of the State.

In understanding and applying section 14 two main features thereof have to be kept in mind. The initiative is that of the Public Prosecutor but Magis­trate has to determine the matter judicially, that is, must exercise a discretion. This would necessarily mean that he has to satisfy himself upon the materi­als before him that for safety of the Stale the trial should be held in camera and that it was not an at­tempt to interfere with the normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons or purposes.

 

In the present case, the allegation relates to the disclosure of a certain secret directive issued by the Government, and this directive has already been pub­lished in the "Pakistan Times". Hence, no question of secrecy arises so far as this document is con­cerned. Ch. Ghulam Muhammad Vs. The State, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 128.

Pakistan (Control of Entry) Act (LV of 1952)

                   Pakistan (Control of Entry) Act (LV of 1952)
 

S. 3 (6)  read with ordinance XXX of 1955

Sub-section (6) applies to the Indians who came into Pakistan prior to 22-10-1955.

The language of sub-section (6) of section 3 of the Act does not leave any doubt that the provisions of that section were introduced to cover not only the Case of Indians who would come into Pakistan on valid travel documents after the 22nd August, 1955 but also the cases of those Indians who had come into Pakistan prior to the 22nd August, 1955 on valid travel documents and overstayed the period mentioned in the visa. Supdt. and Rememb. of L. Affairs Vs. Sunil Kumar Daw (1962) 14 DLR 705.

 

Ss. 3 and 4—Merc submission of an applica­tion for citizenship is not sufficient to exonerate any one from violations of the relevant rules under the Pakistan (Control of Entry) Act. The contention that because the respondent had applied for a Pakistan cit­izenship was sufficient to prevent him from being prosecuted under the said Act is not tenable recognised in International Law which would enable a person by his own voli­tion and by his own act regardless of the will of the State to acquire or terminate a nationality merely by his own choice. A nationality can neither be acquired nor retained except with the will of the State. The State has the right even to deprive a national of his nationality should the occasion arise. Supdt. and Re­membrancer of Legal Affairs, Govt, of E. Pak. Vs. Amalendu Baul (1960) 12 DLR 55 : 1960 PLD (Dac) 329

There is no principle recognised in International Law which would enable a person by his own voli­tion and by his own act regardless of the will of the State to acquire or terminate a nationality merely by his own choice. A nationality can neither be acquired nor retained except with the will of the State. The State has the right even to deprive a national of his nationality should the occasion arise. Supdt. and Re­membrancer of Legal Affairs, Govt, of E. Pak. Vs. Amalendu Baul (1960) 12 DLR 55 : 1960 PLD (Dac) 329.

2493

Words & Phrases

Citation: DLR (SC) 209, (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 209, (1967) 19 DLR 830., (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 209, (1967) 19 DLR 830, (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 9,(1954) 6 DLR (PC) 41, (1950) 2 DLR 151, (1953) 5 DLR (FC) 101. (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 253, (1953) 5 DLR 26, (1950) 2 DLR (PC) 151, (

Subject: Words & Phrases

Delivery Date: 2018-04-25

                                       Judicial Review

 

 

 Judicial review—Vests in the Court with a power correct executive excesses—Occasion when trcisc of the power of judicial review will not resorted to.

 

[These arc matters falling within the scope of ju-gcview which is a power possessed by the pit for correction of executive excesses. Abual Jaududi Vs. Govt, of West Pak. (1965) 17 f of 1850)—S. 1, 2. Judicial Review.DLR (SC) 209.

 

—While considering a matter in exercise of ju­dicial review, if on point of law the administration has adopted a construction, which is a possible one, the Court will support the action.

 

On a point of procedure, it is to be borne in mind that the essential duty is to secure fairness, and when this is present the Court will not interfere.

 

On a point of evidence, it is only when the case proves to be one of "no evidence" that the Courts will intervene and as to the conclusions reached by the executive, the Courts will respect them if all other conditions arc satisfied, just as they respect the judgments of the Courts subordinate to themselves. Abual A.la Maududi Vs. Govt, of West Pak. (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 209.

 

—'Judicial review'—What is meant by judicial review as envisaged by the Supreme Court in Malik Golam Jilani's Case.The Court's duty would be to examine the mate­rials with judicial mind as distinguished from execu­tive outdoor, to see whether there is prima facie ev­idence to justify satisfaction of the Deputy Commissioner in passing the impugned order and not to search for legal evidence produced under strict compliance of proof as in a trial. The Court hence­forth is to examine the reasonableness of the satis­faction and not to refrain from considering the rea­sonableness of the satisfaction on the assumption that this is prohibited. Razaul Malik on behalf of de­tenu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Vs. Government of East Pakistan, (1967) 19 DLR 830.

 

                                                     Judgment—Expungement of

 

Judgment—High Court's judgment—Criticism of, by Judges of the same Court—Limits within which such criticism must operate.

Expungement—Where criticism trespasses le­gitimate limits, offending portions disparaging the Judge must be slashed. Ali Nawaz Gardezi Vs. Lt. Col. Muhammad Yusuf (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 9. 

Jurisdiction

No omission or no acquiescence on the part of counsel confers jurisdiction which is expressly taken away by statute. Adegbite, the Ov/a-Ale Vs. Alasan Babatunde (1954) 6 DLR (PC) 41.

 

—The Court cannot be competent to hear and determine a prosecution the institution of which is prohibited by law. Yusuf Ali Vs. Crown (1950) 2 DLR 151.

 

—Failure of the accused to raise the question of jurisdiction either before the High Court or the Ses­sions Judge or the High Court or even his consent could not confer on the Magistrate the jurisdiction which he did not possess. Asiruddin Vs. Crown (1953) 5 DLR (FC) 101.

 

—Courts exercising special jurisdiction—No appeal to the Crown. Md. Nawaz Vs. Crown (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 253.

—A Magistrate has jurisdiction to try an of­fence created by a special statute if the special stat­ute sets up a tribunal for its trial. Abul Munsur Rahman Vs. Crown (1953) 5 DLR 26

.

—Acquittal order by Court not having jurisdic­tion ultra vires, even if not challenged by way of ap­peal.

The contention was that the trial had proceeded to a point at which most of the prosecution evidence had been given and the Magistrate had framed a charge; that at that stage counsel for the prosecution refused to attempt to prove that a proper sanction had been given or to call further evidence, and that, in the circumstances, the Magistrate had no option but to acquit the accused under section 258, Cr.P.Code.

 

Held : This contention might have had some force if the Magistrate acquitted the accused because he thought the prosecution had failed to prove their case and if he was not asked to decide, and did not decide on the validity of sanction. But the Magis­trate having reached the conclusion that the sanction was bad and the prosecution was incompetent, he ought to have discharged the accused on the ground that he had no jurisdiction to try him The orders of acquittal were passed without ju­risdiction and would only operate as orders of dis­charge. Yusuf Ali Molla Vs. Crown (1950) 2 DLR (PC) 151.

—The contention was that as the orders of ac­quittal passed by the Magistrate in the first prosecu­tion were not appealed from, they became binding on the expiration of the period of limitation under Arti­cle 147, Limitation Act.

 

Held: If the orders of acquittal passed by a Court of competent jurisdiction, though wrongly, they would be binding unless set aside in appeal. But if the orders were a nullity, there was nothing to ap­peal against. Yusuf Ali Molla Vs. Crown (1950)2 DLR (PC) 151.

 

—It may be that the Government, being embar­rassed by the order of acquittal, might have applied to the High Court to quash them. But the omission of the Government to take such a step, which though not incumbent, would not convert an order made without jurisdiction into an order passed by a Court of competent jurisdiction. Yousuf Ali Molla Vs. Crown (1950) 2 DLR (PC) 151.

 

—Under the Common Law, a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict can only be raised where the trial first was before a Court competent to pass valid order of acquittal or conviction. Yusuf Ali Molla Vs. Crown (1950) 2 DLR (PC) 757.

 

Jurisdiction of ordinary Criminal Court includ­ing its jurisdiction to grant bail is barred when the Central Government ordered a case to be tried by Special Tribunal exclusively.

 

The jurisdiction of ordinary Criminal Courts is barred in a case ordered by the Central Government to be tried by a Special Tribunal. The Central Gov­ernment by Notification, not only made the offence (contravention of rule 47, Defence of Pakistan Rules) triable by Special Tribunal but also provided the machinery for trial by constituting a Special Tri­bunal for the Province of West Pakistan. It is thus clear that the jurisdiction of ordinary Criminal Courts was completely ousted in the instant case.

 

Once it is held that the jurisdiction vested exclu­sively in the Special Tribunal it must necessarily follow that no other Court could deal with the mat­ter including the bail application.

 

As soon as the Special Tribunal was constituted the jurisdiction vested in it exclusively including even for the purpose of the decision on the bail ap­plication.

 

With the publication of Notification referred to above by the Central Government the offence com­mitted by the respondent was triable exclusively by the Special Tribunal and as such the considerations laid down in rule 206 of the Defence of Pakistan Rules for the grant of bail applied.

 

The jurisdiction of the High Court in the matter has, in no way, been whittled down except for the considerations laid down in rule 206 of the Defence of Pakistan Rules. The State Vs. Ilabib Jalib, (1968) 20DLR (WP) 1.

 

—Two (penal) laws existing on the same sub­ject—Less stringent one should be resorted to.

 

Two legislations, namely, the Defence of Paki­stan Rules and the Public Safety Ordinance deal with the same subject and the authorities can exercise their power under both the legislations as both are co-existent but in choosing which law is to be re­sorted to the authorities must consider whether the action sought to be corrected or prevented is relatable to the object of the legislation.

 

Examined from this point of view the order is not one which could have been made under rule 32 of the Defence of Pakistan Rules. The provisions of Public Safety Ordinance of 1958 were applicable and adequate even if the act attributed to the detenu could be taken as prejudicial acts. If actions had been taken under the said Ordinance, namely the East Pakistan Public Safety Ordinance of 1958 then the detenu could have had the right of his case being reviewed by the Board set up under the said Ordinance under section 19(b).

 

Even if the authorities arc accepted to have the j discretion to use cither of the two enactments the au­thorities should have resorted to the less stringent

measure, namely the Public Safely Ordinance.

 

Ordinarily, even accepting that the detenu was indulging in prejudicial acts, the ordinary law of the land namely, the Public Safely Ordinance was quite sufficient to meet with the situation. The resort to the Defence of Pakistan Rules was therefore illegal. Rczaul Malik on behalf of detenu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Vs. Government of East Pakistan, (1967) 19 DIM 831.
